------=_NextPart_000_04BB_01CAC596.D4BA0ED0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Joel,
 
First, I agree with much your characterizations of novelty search.  I would
however like to amplify that novelty searches can also identify structural
similarities and differences, including RBF that encode distances in
addition to weight of the network topology.  This means that clustering
patterns and various "geographic" features can be associated / disassociated
with the genome and its behaviors.
 
This can be used to avoid overly focused "sunny day paradoxes" in the
solution space.  In other words, it helps us understand the concept of
"fitness" in various contexts, so not only is the search open-ended, but the
criteria may be open-ended as well.
 
Ken Lloyd
 
 


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
joel278
Sent: Wednesday, March 17, 2010 12:12 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: Novelty Search


  



The basic concept of novelty search is to explore the space of behaviors in
a particular domain. This is accomplished by rewarding individuals that
display behaviors that are different from those seen prior in a search. 

In contrast, fitness-based search will generally reward individuals
according to some fixed measure of progress. A significant benefit of
novelty search when compared to fitness search is that novelty search is not
generally susceptible to the problem of "deception" where following the
gradients of the fitness function lead to dead-ends in the search space.
Deception is the reason that fitness functions must often be carefully
crafted and tweaked in order to solve difficult problems.

Interestingly, sometimes exploring the behavior space may lead novelty
search to find the solution to a problem, though it was not directly trying
to. Counter-intuitively, it may consistently be faster at finding the
objective than an objective-based search in deceptive problems.

Searching for behavioral novelty is different from an exhaustive search of
the genotype space for many reasons. As you wrote, many genotypes may map to
the same behavior; novelty search may avoid many of these equivalent
behaviors because once that area of behavior space has been thoroughly
explored, it will not reward individuals displaying those behaviors, and
will instead focus search on variations of genotypes that are demonstrating
more novel behaviors.

In addition, the domain itself imposes limits on behaviors; for example,
physics constrains our behaviors, we cannot walk through solid objects.
Further, demonstrating novelty may often require learning about a domain.
For example, to appear novel, a maze navigational robot may need to learn
about walls and how to avoid them . In fact, this is what happens in the
maze domain explored in the ALifeXI paper. So, novelty search may be in some
sense about transferring information from the domain into genotypes.

An exciting aspect of novelty search is that the search is open-ended and
can potentially continue endlessly finding novel behaviors that may grow in
complexity. While a fitness-based search may have little to do after it has
solved a particular problem, novelty search can continue to find new
behaviors even after it is has uncovered a solution. 

I hope that this addressed some of your questions.

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com,
"lior_fainshil" <lior_fainshil@...> wrote:
>
> I read the original article and thread about novelty search and found it
very interesting. It would be interesting to hear if there are better
insights about the idea now.
> In particular I want to understand how is the novelty search better than a
systematic or a random search of the genotype space. A brute force search of
the genotype will certainly run on many occasions into the same phenotypes.
The question is to what extent can novelty search avoid this and does it
have other benefits?
> 
> ps.
> I attended Ken's tutorial on developmental systems on GECCO2008, and in my
opinion, it was by far the best presentation I saw on that conference.
That's how I got introduced to NEAT. Now I decided to take a look at it
again and I am finding many interesting ideas.
>
